awd_titl_txt: Core Support for the National Academy of Sciences' Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology (BCST) and Chemical Sciences Roundtable (CSR)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Divisions of Chemistry (CHE) and Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (CBET) fund this award to the National Academy of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine. This award supports the core activities of both the Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology (BCST) and the Chemical Sciences Roundtable (CSR). The results of BCST and CSR discussions and workshops are disseminated through workshop reports made available through professional societies, scientific and trade publications, and on the web. 

The BCST has broad representation from academe and industry and uses its collective expertise to identify the needs of the community.  The BCST provides peer-reviewed consensus reports, workshops, and symposia. The BCST enhances the impacts of the chemistry and chemical engineering communities by engaging in questions of importance to federal decision-makers. BCST members oversee a portfolio of ad hoc studies in key areas of education, workforce, and research issues. Specific areas of consideration for this funding period include: single cell/single molecule measurement, sustainable chemical manufacturing, quantum computing and its implications for chemistry, attracting and retaining student in undergraduate chemical education, incorporating new elements in chemical education such as data science and entrepreneurship. By raising issues impacting the conduct of chemistry and chemical engineering research with federal officials, BCST helps assure that the community of practitioners can remain at the forefront of knowledge. The CSR provides an apolitical forum for leaders in the chemical sciences and engineering, with the objective of enhancing understanding of issues that affect government, academic, national laboratory, and nonprofit sectors. CSR discussions provide a vehicle for interaction among the participants/  These participants discuss and report on education, exchange of information, and issues and trends that affect the chemical sciences. CSR engages leading scientists and engineers to identify and explore, through workshops, emerging topics of importance to the chemical community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology (BCST) enhances the broader impacts of the chemistry and chemical engineering community by engaging their expertise in questions of importance to federal decision-makers. This is done primarily through the ad hoc studies it oversees. BCST convenes top experts to conduct research and share their insights on pressing chemical science and engineering issues. Our goal is to provide our nation’s decision makers with the highest quality scientific and technical advice. It proactively raises topics of importance to the larger chemical enterprise to federal officials at its meetings and in other networking activities. We work in eight strategic areas: basic research; chemical and energy industries; biochemistry; environmental chemistry; pharmaceutical chemistry; electrochemistry; national security; and education and workforce development.

The mission of the Chemical Sciences Roundtable (CSR), an ongoing activity of the BCST, is to provide a science-oriented, apolitical forum to discuss and enhance understanding of the critical issues in chemical science and technology affecting the government, industrial, and academic sectors. It is not a source of advice for federal officials, but an educational vehicle for exchange of information that could lead to follow-up action by private-sector participants and their parent organizations. CSR plans and hosts 1 workshop annually on a topic deemed particularly important to the chemical sciences community, for which summaries are published, but no recommendations are made. Additionally, the CSR hosts 3 short webinars per calendar year to bring attention to and start conversations around topics of importance.

The BCST held 9 business meetings from 09/01/2018 - 08/31/2021, three of which were held in person, where the appointed members of the board discussed the ongoing activities within BCST and to hear from invited speakers on potential topics of interest for future activities. During this period, the following consensus studies and proceedings were completed by BCST and are available free for download at https://www.nap.edu/author/BCST/division-on-earth-and-life-studies/board-on-chemical-sciences-and-technology?author=BCST&n=10&start=0:

  • Peer Review of Interim Report on Computational Fluid Dynamics Model for Predicting Wellhead Oil-Burning Efficiency at Bench and Intermediate Scales (2021)
  • Innovations in Pharmaceutical Manufacturing on the Horizon: Technical Challenges, Regulatory Issues, and Recommendations (2021)
  • Report of the Committee on Proposal Evaluation for Allocation of Supercomputing Time for the Study of Molecular Dynamics: Eleventh Round (2020)
  • Innovations in Pharmaceutical Manufacturing: Proceedings of a Workshop—in Brief (2020)
  • Strategies for Identifying and Addressing Vulnerabilities Posed by Synthetic Biology: Proceedings of a Workshop–in Brief (2019)
  • A Research Agenda for Transforming Separation Science (2019)
  • Continuous Manufacturing for the Modernization of Pharmaceutical Production: Proceedings of a Workshop (2019)
  • Environmental Engineering for the 21st Century: Addressing Grand Challenges (2019)
  • Negative Emissions Technologies and Reliable Sequestration: A Research Agenda (2019)
  • Gaseous Carbon Waste Streams Utilization: Status and Research Needs (2019)
  • Report of the Committee on Proposal Evaluation for Allocation of Supercomputing Time for the Study of Molecular Dynamics: Ninth Round (2018)

There are several ongoing consensus studies within the BCST, including:

  • Carbon Utilization Infrastructure, Markets, Research and Development
  • Identifying Opportunities at the Interface of Chemistry and Quantum Information Science
  • The Chemistry of Urban Wildfires
  • Emerging Science on Indoor Chemistry
  • Enhancing the U.S. Chemical Economy through Investments in Fundamental Research in the Chemical Sciences
  • Chemical Engineering: Challenges and Opportunities in the 21st Century

The CSR held 7 business meetings from 09/01/2018 - 08/31/2021 to discuss and determine the topics for the webinars and workshops. During this period, the roundtable hosted four (5) 1.5 day workshops and six (6) 1.5 hour webinars (listed below). Proceedings in brief are published following each workshop and are available free for download at https://www.nap.edu/initiative/chemical-sciences-roundtable.

Workshops:

  • Laboratory Automation and Accelerated Synthesis: Empowering Tomorrow’s Chemist (2021)
  • Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in Chemistry and Chemical Engineering (2021)
  • Advances, Challenges, and Long-Term Opportunities in Electrochemistry: Addressing Societal Needs (2019)
  • Closing the Loop on the Plastics Dilemma (2019)
  • Astrochemistry: Discoveries to Inform the Chemical Sciences and Engineering Communities (2018)

Webinars:

  • Future Directions of Sustainability in Chemical Manufacturing (2021)
  • Advances in the Chemistry of CO2 Capture (2021)
  • The Future of Sustainable Agrochemistry (2020)
  • The U.S. Chemical Supply Chain: Vulnerabilities Highlighted by COVID-19 (2020)
  • Novel Synthetic Opioid Detection: Analytical and Other Challenges (2020)
  • Inorganic Biohybrids: Advancing Artificial Photosynthesis (2020)

 

BCST and CSR provide access to information on all of their activities through their respective websites, https://www.nationalacademies.org/bcst/board-on-chemical-sciences-and-technologyand https://www.nationalacademies.org/our-work/chemical-sciences-roundtable. A dissemination plan and outreach strategy is developed for every report and workshop summary. Utilizing the BCST and CSR communications associate in addition to the communications team at the National Academies, we disseminate our publications using a variety of channels. All newsletters, posts, and communications are tailored for their individualized platforms to provide the most effective and impactful dissemination of our studies and events.
